awd_titl_txt: Stereotype-based contagion in Problem Based Learning Contexts and STEM Identification
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. As part of ECR, this project is funded by the Research on Gender in Science and Engineering (GSE) program. GSE seeks to understand and address gender-based differences in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and workforce participation through education and implementation research that will lead to a larger and more diverse domestic STEM workforce. This project will focus on understanding why girls and women who are initially the most invested and motivated to succeed in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematic (STEM) domains, are ironically the most likely to leave these domains. The research specifically will examine a social context that has received little research to date: Problem Based Learning (PBL). With the PBL approach individuals work on problems together in dyads or groups. Although this approach is gaining rapid popularity at all levels of education, the role that it may play in affecting girls' and women's performance and ultimately their identification with STEM fields remains unexplored. This research proposes that PBL settings may be threatening to at least one individual target in a task group. This threat may in turn spread to other women in the group--a phenomenon referred to as stereotype-based stress contagion--affecting all female group members' performance and memories of the situation accordingly. Using a multi-method approach that includes psychophysiological, neurological, and behavioral measures, the studies will explore how PBL settings may unintentionally create stereotype or social identity threatening contexts, i.e., stressful, physiologically arousing situations where negative stereotypes about women's math ability are salient. The studies also will investigate a series of downstream consequences of this process within individuals. For example, stress contagion may facilitate encoding of negative memories specific to the PBL context, even if group members were otherwise more resilient to threats. Importantly, negative emotional memories forged in PBL contexts may lay the foundation for learned aversions towards STEM domains that undermine STEM identification over time.

The research has five primary objectives: 1) Investigate whether stereotype-based stress experienced by one woman will spread to otherwise non-threatened male and female partners in interpersonal interactions, as reflected in synchronous neural, physiological and behavioral responses between two partners; 2) Assess whether stereotype-based stress contagion will engender worse dyadic performance and partner perceptions; 3) Determine whether stereotype-based stress contagion facilitates encoding of negative, stereotype confirming information among the partner placed under threat and her female interaction partner; 4) Examine whether stereotype-based stress contagion engenders learned STEM aversions that undermine feelings of competency among two or more stigmatized individuals in a group; and 5) Assess these processes in a highly unique but optimal real-world setting: High school freshman boys and girls who have chosen a STEM track and work regularly in Problem Based Learning contexts to solve STEM related problems. These studies will employ a variety of longitudinal, social and cognitive neuroscience methodologies, including EEG, psychophysiological and dyadic methodologies. This approach stands to provide a mechanistic understanding of how neural and psychophysiological biomarkers interact both within and between individuals to alter overt perceptions, behaviors and thus interactions between two individuals in PBL contexts; mechanisms that might otherwise be impossible to identify relying on behavioral or self-report measures alone.

por.por_cntn:
Through various studies at UD and NYU, both applied and laboratory-based and spanning different developmental groups, overarching findings from this proposal provide insight into the potentially deleterious, pervasive interpersonal dynamics that arise during dyadic and group interactions between individuals who are positively stereotyped in STEM (e.g., white males) and individuals who are negatively stereotyped in STEM (e.g., women and people of color). When stressed stigmatized individuals interact with positively stereotyped, non-stigmatized individuals these issues can take the form of underperforming on STEM-relevant tasks, not being recognized by their non-stigmatized counterparts in group interactions, feeling more stressed in the situation (both neurally and physiologically), or feeling more negative affect following STEM-based group interactions. Paradoxically, while the presence of other stigmatized individuals in the group/dyad may help alleviate some of these outcomes in stressed stigmatized individuals, particularly with respect to performance and neural indices of stress, their otherwise initially non-stressed partners may “catch” this stress and underperform in STEM contexts as a result. Nevertheless, findings across studies provide a potential roadmap for attenuating the detrimental consequences of stigma on group interactions. One promising path is to strive for changing the institution, e.g., the classroom setting, and parameters in which diverse group interactions are carried out. This can be achieved by creating more identity-safe contexts that help blunt stress responses among the stigmatized at their source (e.g., avoid outnumbering stigmatized individuals with non-stigmatized group members as these contexts are known to prime gender or ethnicity and thus stereotype-based stress). Findings from this proposal provide a potential blueprint for how teachers and administrators can organize classroom group interactions in a way that can account for both the individual needs of individuals who are underrepresented in STEM, as well as the individuals whose bias undermines stigmatized individuals otherwise earnest efforts to engage with STEM.  Employing strategies such as this could help women and people of color stay engaged with STEM domains, an outcome that would diversify and increase the size of the applicant pool that STEM programs and industry draw from. This would benefit society in multiple ways by fortifying the nation’s economy, academic and corporate diversity, national productivity, innovation and quality of STEM products, services and education. This in turn could help increase the overall quality of life of many of the country's citizens.

Consistent with the general impetus for the studies conducted in this grant, dozens of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, many of whom stem from underrepresented groups, have been trained in cutting edge neuroscience techniques and complex statistical methods. This training has helped propel many of these individuals to careers in STEM, graduate school, and faculty and principal investigator positions respectively. Furthermore, research conducted in this proposal has yielded several valuable data sets that are now available to the public (all of which are stored on the Open Science Framework). All data sets contain information relevant to the goals of this project, including data on people’s physiology during the experiments we conducted (e.g., their heart rate), as well as the behaviors they displayed (e.g., how much they talked to a work partner and asked about math). Data sets all contain data labels, so it is clear what each variable is referring to. Code for analyzing data are also available (along with descriptors of what each line of code means).  

In addition, Tessa West has created several "how to" guides for those interested in learning more about how to collect and analyze data, that resulted from the projects in this grant. All guides are available on her lab youtube website (search for "West Interpersonal perception lab" or go to: https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=west+interpersonal+perception+lab).
